Real Rating: 77.5/100
Critics love Tarantino because he loves cinema and they can associate with that, and they get all of his references, which can be lost on your average viewer. It is the same reason movies set in LA often get a few noms or wins during Oscar season that many would call questionable. This is not to detract from Tarantino's talent. The man is a great writer, though as of late he has become a blowhard. Scripts are long and drawn out, and then they all crash into an ending that seems tacked on rather than built to which begs the question does he even know where he is going with his films anymore. It is not visionary, it is repetitive and showing very little sign of growth. He is a craftsman who carves an excellent movie each time, but they are more or less the same.

DE: Tarantino runs a decent ship, and Hollywood is no different. Everything seems to be on point. Every department is hitting its marks, and we are building a tale in his distinct (if that is the right word) style. In terms of editing, the loss of Sally Menke can be felt in every one of his films since she passed. She somehow was able to contain him and give a better structure. Though from seeing her works outside of the Tarantino verse, you can see he had an equal part in elevating her. Together they were able to take his longwinded approach and make it come off with a steady pace and allow decent investment from the audience, but now however that is slipping away at a fast pace with each subsequent film.

W: Tarantino is one of the great writers, he is not on Miyazaki's or Anderson's level, but he is undoubtedly on the same level as the Coen brothers or Bong Joon-ho. Which is not a level to sniff at, but the problem with Tarantino's writing is that he may have switched genres, but he has not adapted to it. More that he has made another Tarantino movie with a new shell on it. Which is great, but if I wanted to see the same thing as before I might as well watch the classics. It is sort of like a band doing a new tour 20 years later trying to flog the new stuff that sounds far too similar to the old stuff, and the fans would much rather prefer to hear the hits.

C: Have you seen a Tarantino, Scorsese or Oliver Stone movie? Then guess what you have seen Robert Richardson's work and along with it some iconic shots that have littered avatars and uni students bedrooms for decades. His outing this time is impressive, though it might not match a level that he created. That said the lens seems to tell more of a story here than Tarantino's writing, which tells you everything you need to know.

A: Acting is stereotypically cartoonish, but that has become a standard for Tarantino. Though Pitt's depiction of the more sane character throughout this 2D world of actors stands out. Sadly given the cast, we are working with, and the sheer level of talent coupled with the extent in which we examine these characters lives it feels underwhelming, and each one is more an allegory than a persona in their own right.

S: As strange as it seems the sound department is usually one of the reasons I watch a Tarantino film. Since Inglourious Basterds someone in the sound department is getting an Oscar nom, whether it is music, mixing or editing. Without fail Hollywood continues this trend. Just excellent.

PD: This film is not pretending to be the 1960s, it is the 1960s. I know you have seen many a period piece, and they all do a decent job, but it is the subtle nuances and the dirt that make the difference. This is not a glossy veneer trying to rewrite a section of history, this is just trying to capture an era for better or worse. This may be down to the fact that Tarantino is obsessed with the period and only a slight glance at his oeuvre would back this notion up.

BA: The costume design, while simple is also great, it catches the style of the era without feeling like it is overexaggerating the form or the zeitgeist of the time. The visual effects in the latter portion of the film while jarring are quite well done and stand out.

EVO: It is not one of Tarantino's "funner" films, which is odd given that it is a bright nostalgia backed film told from the perspective of mostly positive souls. If you are a Tarantino completest, you are going to want to see it, but for many, the question of why did I sit through that for 3 hours will ring true on the lips, and while the film is crafted brilliantly I cannot help but finding myself siding with them.

Both DiCaprio and Pitt were superb, and so was Tarantino. He toyed with my head, making me think that it would all boil down to what really happened in 1969. His deflective tactic of bringing all these bits and stories together and creating something entirely new really was something I should have expected, but clearly didn't. He never fails to bring in a lot of pop culture references along with long dialogue sequences, which brings me to my next comment. I don't think you'll need 2h and 41m to capture all the essence, and Robbie's role as Sharon Tate could have had more lines and substance apart from looking pretty.

I am putting 3 stars because I know it's a quality movie, and it's easy to hang out with Pitt & DeCaprio for 2+ hours.... but, I fear I am getting too simple to enjoy Tarantino movies.  2 hours and 40 minutes... slow pace, mild dialogue, a plot that only exists for character development... I honestly don't know what the movie was about... or what I'll remember in a week.  And a gory finish as has become his trademark.  Sadly, I may need quick jokes, explosions, or superheroes. ;-P

Tarantino has become iconic and actors salivate to play a role in his films, however he has not transcended beyond the guttural, gratuitous violence and shock factor that put him on the cinematic map. 'Once upon a time in hollywood' is a snooze fest wrapped as a love story to glory days. The payoff in the last 20 mins was anti-climatic. None of the characters were memorable, rather washouts and full of self doubt. The biggest proof that this was a weak installment is the fact that not a single meme has entered popular culture from this film, unlike Tarantino's other works. Similar to 'The Last Jedi', the critics are falling over themselves to praise his snooze fest, out of FOMO than anything else. If Tarantino intends to end at film 10, he better knock it out of the park, otherwise unlike Michael Jordan, he will leave too late.

If you enjoy the subtle humor and slow burn story telling of filmmakers like the Coen Brothers and (of course) Quentin Tarantino, you might just love Once Upon a Time in Hollywood. The performances, especially from Pitt and DiCaprio are superb, the cinematography is basically flawless. Every shot could be a still picture with perfect composition. Every scene is basically a vignette short story that could stand on its own, and if there is any flaw in the movie, that's probably it. It's less about plot, and more about interesting and likable characters put in situations that range from mundane to utterly ridiculous. It's possible that the average movie goer will overlook  some of the little bits of ubiquitous humor and nostalgia, and if so, the movie could feel slow, and perhaps even boring. But if you enjoy all the little things that make a Tarantino film a Tarantino film, this is for me, his most lighthearted (with the exception of a couple scenes) and his most "watchable" movie to date. I will be re-watching this in the same way I have re-watched movies like Fight Club, or the Big Lebowski. The characters are magnetic and there are lots of little things to notice and enjoy if you're looking for them.

I can't tell you what seeing a white, short jean jacket and matching white jeans on a man again does to me, it would be unseemly to say. I really don't see movies when they first come out, I never did. I was going to save this one for a while yet, but...the preview had Brad Pitt doing his western tang drawl and...it rained here, so...damn I'm glad I bought this movie today. It was so worth it, and it was like a good read. You put it on the shelf and pull it out when you really need it. Also, okay, never mind, nobody spoiled this one for me, no one gave me a clue, so I'm not going to do it to you by explaining what, exactly, it has in common with "Inglorious Basterds," and don't mean Brad Pitt doing the drawl which reminds me of my Missouri relations. How can I say it and keep from ruining the story for those that haven't read it yet?  Look. Mr. Tarantino will occasionally present a revisionistic take on a historical subject that gives those who suffered vicariously, a relief valve that I, for one, never knew I needed until I got it.

Watching this movie was painful. If you were born anytime 1975, you likely will have no idea what is happening in the movie until the very end. In the meantime, you watch plodding sequence of seemingly unrelated scenes about average Hollywood personnel living their average Hollywood lives. Don't get me wrong, the performances of Brad Pitt, Leo, and company are tremendous, as is the style and settings. I believe they captured the time period in amazing fashion and detail, even down to a soundtrack which doesn't include the stereotypical songs. For these reasons, you can get to 2 stars, but as a movie, it was terrible except for the last 10 minutes and a few scenes here or there. If you have to go outside the movie to get the plot, then you have failed as a storyteller, and assuming that the entire viewing audience is intimately familiar with the happenings of the Manson Murders is a glaring mistake from the get go.

Wish Fulfilment

Tarantino's scrupulously reconstructs 1969 Hollywood to create an alternative end to the 1960's, but to what end? Once again, he has made an enjoyable, overlong and seemingly pointless re-imagining (think Inglorious Bastards, Hateful 8, etc) that pervades his private fantasies, instead of an original narrative.

Of course, 1969 featured Woodstock and Altamont, but the Manson killings was the quintessential, bleak end of that exciting decade. And here, Tarantino imagines a clear clash between early 1960's macho culture confronting a debased late 1960's hippie disaster, with the macho culture coming out on top. With both Pitt and DiCaprio on top form as a tough stunt man (think Clint Eastwood) and fading, insecure Western star (no obvious parallel I know of), most of the film seems to be wallowing in their relationship. But the real story is the scheduled murder of next store neighbour Sharon Tate by the Manson crazies in August. We are waiting for it - how will Tarantino deal with it? It will be gruesome that's for sure. But what do these macho neighbours have to do with it?

Well, that's the real tale. What if the Manson family made a slightly different turn and missed Terry Melcher's old house and invaded Leo and Brad's pad? Quite a different outcome from the real story. The blood bath was on the other foot, with the macho boys dispensing ruthless frontier justice on the home invaders.

Despite the length, I found it captivating, weird, beautiful and disgusting all at the same time. The message was clear - if drug crazed hippies are out to kill you, a couple of tough guys with a pit bull and a flame thrower will save you from a fate worse than Covid-19.

My Netflix review, repurposed: I like Tarantino. I like this film. It's not boring or over long as some reviewers think. It's not inaccessible to people who didn't live through the '60's as written in some media reviews, because if that were true, all of the films I've watched & enjoyed that were set in the Stone Age (Quest For Fire), the Roman Empire (I Claudius), the Middle Ages (Marketa Lazarova) the 16th, 17th, 18th (Jane Austin's "Emma" or "Pride and Prejudice") 19th ("Wuthering Heights") centuries & the complete 20th century (everything), wouldn't have been relatable to or understood by me. I wasn't bored by THOSE films because I'm a reader. I had a good public education. I strived for the best grades I could get in K through 12, I didn't drop out or ignore my teachers during class and I did my homework. I went to college by working from age 14, saved every penny, got huge loans that took me 30 years to pay off, & I received a good education that required me to read, read, read, & learn from my instructors & professors how to interpret those books, whether text books or novels or non-fiction writings. It expanded my brain so that I am able to do the same thing with movies, so I'm not bored by them. I can enjoy movies that are really well crafted like this one. This film is the work of an evolving director, who didn't "make up a stupid boring long thing with too much talking about something that didn't even happen that way" (I'm not quoting anyone. I'm combining all of the negatives I've read/heard everywhere into one paraphrase). He gave us a "what if", & nice "if only". It's not boring. Tons of funny things happen in short bursts throughout the film & are cleverly brought back together in that final blast that is the ultimate Tarantinoed "what if" that pays homage to Sharon Tate & the others who were tortured & killed by the Manson Family. It might disappoint a Tarantino fan who has not yet matured at the same rate. It might be better later, with more accrued observation/thinking skills.

I've been a big fan of Tarantino's since Reservoir Dogs and have emencly enjoyed his films for years. The always unique director and writer always seems to surprise with his completely unpredictable films. Now that that's been said, I finally got through Once Upon a time in Hollywood. I tried watching this film five times and always turned it off. I finally got through it, even fast forwarding thru sections of the film, to finally finish it was pretty unbearable. Tarantino's worst film to date! My first thoughts after finishing the film were ''what a piece of shit''. I habe never said this about any of his films and it is a shame. This unimaginative version of real life events skewed to Tarantino's will, was boring, overly long (by about an hour) and just muddled story of a falling Hollywood star and his decent from stardom leave much to be desired. This may have been a decent film on it's own prwemise but the added mix of the Tate/Manson murders just doesn't work. Expected better from a giant. The only decent parts of the movie are Brad Pitt and sadly, the best part of the film was the dog.

I agree it's meandering and underwhelming. But it is a coolly acted, beautifully produced movie which reminds us of a shift in Hollywood in the 70s and how it mirrors Hollywood today, which is changing ever more rapidly. If Tarantino had utilized the premise's potential more, it would make a strong contender.

In the late 60s, the actor Rick Dalton tries to adapt to the new times. His double and best friend, Cliff Booth, has problems to find a job because people think he killed his wife. Also, Cliff has to move Rick around by car because Dalton's driver's license has been suspended due to drive drunk. At the same time, a relationship is born between Rick and actress Sharon Tate, who was a victim of the Manson family in the 1969 massacre.

This is basically the movie summarized.
You have this fading actor who tries to stay relevant , but is quickly fading.
His more down to earth stunt double who has a shitty life and killed his wife follows him everywhere like a loyal dog.
In the end the entire movie revolves around one thing... the fading actor meeting his new generation actor friends who live next door and hooking up with them in order to survive and he lets his stunt double friend ride to the hospital alone even though he saved his life ... showing that in order to make it in Hollywood you have to leave friends behind ... all other things in this movie are random filler and never really matter ... even the manson thing is just a vehicle to deliver that message.

To me it is just a mediocre, fringing on bad B movie ... not worthy to even stand in the shadow of all other "Once upon a time ..." type movies
